data.text: Who Uses an E-Bike for Long-Distance Touring and Camping?

Who uses an ebike? I have a RadRunner Plus that i have never used for long distance. I have two batteries and each on a full charge is supposed to get 40+ miles. I am contemplating using it for a 110 mile trip so that I can easily bring a trailer. I was thinking I would start early and ride till the first is dead and find a coffee shop or something to chill and recharge for about 4 hours and then finishing the ride. I am mainly curious on any challenges ebike riders have had vs a normal bike. I don't normally have problems doing a century on a normal bike but this time around I will be camping for two weeks in one location and want to carry more gear than usual.

data.text: I have a Magnum ebike and two batteries. It says maximum mileage is 35 miles per battery. My bike has 5 pedal assist levels. I can get 80-90 miles out of one battery if I keep it on pedal assist 1 and pedal also. I would use pedal assist 2 for hills. I was amazed! If I ride at a higher pedal assist level and pedal hard also, I can get 60-70 miles out of that 35-mile battery. But if I let the bike do a lot or most of the work, I donâ€™t get near the higher mileage.

data.text: Drive half way to your first stop on one battery, then switch batteries and drive an equal distance on the second battery. When you stop, charge both batteries concurrently for 2x the total charge rate. Of course you need two chargers. If you really want to do long distance make a custom lithium titanate pack that can quick charge in 20-40 minutes using 12-15amps of 110v household current and which you pull on a trailer because it will weigh some 35 lbs.

data.text: Range may very due to topography, weather, and load weight. On a overnighter rode there and back (50 miles) on one charge. Next time I had strong headwinds and barely made it there. Another time I rode my ebike down the Oregon coast on a self supported ride. Day 2 I underestimated the topography and skipped my midday charge. I was a few miles short of the top. Pushing a 50 pound bike overloaded with 50 pounds of gear for several miles was a unforgettable learning experience. Did stayed a campgrounds with a power source every night to fully charge my battery. After that I stopped once everyday for a hardy breakfast and topped off my battery while eating and would plug in during any break with facilities. No range anxiety after that. Note: I always asked permission to plug in.
data.author: Tony Rice
